 December 30, 2005
 Editorial
 A College Sports Scam 
 The myth of salvation through college and professional sports is a blight on poor communities all over the country. Suckered into chasing a chimerical "ticket out of the ghetto," young people devote every waking moment to athletics while neglecting studies that would actually prepare them for reachable careers. Those who get to college at all often play their hearts out until they are no longer eligible and end up back on the streets - without hope, prospects or even college degrees. 
 
 The National Collegiate Athletic Association has tried to break this cycle by gradually raising admissions requirements for athletes. The point was to force parents, schools and players to get serious about their high school education. But a recent scandal at a Florida diploma mill, exposed by Pete Thamel and Duff Wilson of The Times, shows that the N.C.A.A. has a lot more work to do before it reaches this goal. 
 
 The story involves University High School, a transparently bogus correspondence school that offered high school degrees for a pittance, but had no classes or instructors and operated virtually without oversight. Athletes who had failed courses they needed to qualify were offered easy-listening studies and pathetically simple tests that allowed them to polish up their transcripts in no time at all. They were then funneled into some of the most important football programs in the country and, predictably, have not fared well.
 
 The N.C.A.A., which was slow off the mark when the scam came to light, has since appointed a panel that will examine correspondence schools and other "nontraditional" institutions that feed athletes into the billion-dollar business known as college sports. 
 
 The panel should not stop there. At the very least, it needs to develop methods for scanning academic records for unexplained jumps in student achievement. Something is clearly fishy when a failing athlete switches schools and ends up with a transcript that conveniently meets the N.C.A.A. qualifications for college athletes. 
 
 The N.C.A.A. academic reforms, started two decades ago, were supposed to end the exploitation of athletes and send the message that players needed to learn and graduate if they wanted to compete at the big-time college level. The dust-up in Florida should remind everyone involved that the job of reforming college sports is far from finished.
